title: Definition of PROTOCOL
description: an original draft, minute, or record of a document or transaction; a preliminary memorandum often formulated and signed by diplomatic negotiators as a basis for a final convention or treaty... See the full definition
cleaned_text: protocol [noun](/dictionary/noun) pro·to·col [pr-t-kl](/dictionary/protocol?pronunciation&lang=en_us&dir=p&file=protoc01) -kl, -käl, -kl 1 : an original draft, minute, or record of a document or transaction 2 a : a preliminary memorandum often formulated and signed by [diplomatic](/dictionary/diplomatic)negotiators as a basis for a final convention or treaty b : the records or minutes of a diplomatic conference or congress that show officially the agreements arrived at by the negotiators 3 a : a code prescribing strict adherence to correct [etiquette](/dictionary/etiquette)and [precedence](/dictionary/precedence)(as in diplomatic exchange and in the military services) a breach of protocol b : a set of conventions governing the treatment and especially the formatting of data in an electronic communications system network protocols 4 : a detailed plan of a scientific or medical experiment, treatment, or procedure Example Sentences Typically, those who make pronouncements like this assume (without saying so) that the tongues making up the multitude will belong to persons who are committed to the protocols of rational inquiry; frivolous persons, persons who exploit those protocols or play with them to gain political ends, are not imagined. —Stanley Fish, Harper's, December 2005 Purcell even flouted the timeless protocol of pretending to admire the work of his fellow editors. —Tobias Wolff, Old School, 2003 Today, thanks to the civil-rights movement, white guilt is propriety—an utterly invisible code that defines decency in our culture with thousands of little protocols we no longer even think about. —Shelby Steele, Harper's, November 2002 The soldier's actions constitute a breach of military protocol. They did not follow the proper diplomatic protocols. What is the proper protocol for declining a job offer? the Geneva Protocol of 1925 [See More](javascript:void(0)) Recent Examples on the Web McCain was placed the league's concussion protocol after the play. —oregonlive, 2 Sep. 2023 As per protocol with any death investigation, the Tuscaloosa Violent Crimes Unit responded to the scene. —Carol Robinson | Crobinson@al.com, al, 30 Aug. 2023 The university has increased its surface cleaning and sanitizing protocols to help mitigate the spread. —Doug Thompson, Arkansas Online, 29 Aug. 2023 Shey Peddy remains in concussion protocol after a scary head injury earlier this month. —Jenna Ortiz, The Arizona Republic, 28 Aug. 2023 It's run by a team of healers including a medical doctor, and protocols range from blood tests to Tension & Trauma Releasing Exercises to myofascial massage. —Mary Holland, Robb Report, 27 Aug. 2023 Instead, a spokesperson for Mejia said in a pair of emails that the office followed the proper protocol by sending a letter about York's nomination to the city clerk, which was uploaded to the public council file. —David Zahniser, Los Angeles Times, 26 Aug. 2023 The San Diego Police Department is investigating the shooting per a countywide protocol that ensures agencies don't investigate shootings involving their own officers. —Caleb Lunetta, San Diego Union-Tribune, 25 Aug. 2023 Jordan Addison will not be in action after head coach Kevin O'Connell said the first-round receiver is in concussion protocol. —Jordan Mendoza, USA TODAY, 20 Aug. 2023 [See More](javascript:void(0)) These examples are programmatically compiled from various online sources to illustrate current usage of the word 'protocol.'
